Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\), where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. We examine the effect of a linear transformation defined by the matrix \\( A \\), where \\( A = \\begin{pmatrix} \cos \phi & -\sin \phi \\ \sin \phi & \cos \phi \\end{pmatrix} \\) representing a rotation by an angle \\( \phi \\) on the complex plane.

Knowing the function \\( z(t) \\) at time t = T, can we identify whether a rotation by \\( A \\) was applied at t = 0?
Explanation: Since rotation preserves the nature of the trajectory on the complex plane, the rotated trajectory \\( Az(t) \\) still forms a circular path, indistinguishable from the original \\( z(t) \\). Thus, observing the nature of the trajectory at T does not reveal whether the initial state was rotated.
